<p>In this episode of <strong>What Da Math</strong>, <strong>Anton P</strong> discusses optimal takeoff velocity in KSP.</p>
yea i never really worry about fuel when launching...

"The only time you have too much fuel is when you're on fire" - Anonymous

'Nuff said

Very helpful vid. I hope you do go into the math (a bit) on your next one. The Goddard Dilemma doesn't get much attention at all, even though it is so crucial to our missions. So thank you! AFAIK, this hasn't been addressed since Closette's Goddard Challenge thread back in 0.13, which I can't find anymore.Ã¯Â»Â¿

The YouTube comments got into a discussion about the gravity turn. Way back in the olden days, I did about 50 test flights with one rocket and MJ, adjusting the turn shape and turn start altitude each time. Here's a graph of my results:

Basically, the best was to start at 8km and a slightly shallow shape (33%). Very steep ascents (67% and 75%) were horribly inefficient. In the related challenge thread, we figured out that we should adjust that curve to keep our rockets at terminal velocity Vt. So a slow rocket should turn lower and flatter, while a fast rocket should turn higher and steeper.

The exact figures will change with the updated drag model. But the principles will still apply.

...Closette's Goddard Challenge thread back in 0.13, which I can't find anymore.Ã¯Â»Â¿..
Found it! For those interested in the math around the Goddard Dilemma, enjoy!

http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/6664-Mini-challenge-max-altitude-with-this-supplied-spacecraft

Also, it's a fun challenge to try and optimize throttle by hand.
"What Da Math"? I thought there will be less pitching to 45 at 10k and more, you know, math. Preferably with FAR, but even without it - where's the math in "What Da Math"?

All this is based on the stock drag model, where terminal velocity is the same for ALL craft designs (a lead ball and a plastic plate or feather would fall at *EXACTLY* the same rate inside the atmosphere with this model), which is of course preposterous...

Basically, the key concept is that it's most efficient to ascend at terminal velocity. "Cheat sheets" about what that velocity is for ALL CRAFT won't work anymore with a drag model that simulates drag based on shape rather than mass. A larger (bigger rockets have higher terminal velocity due to the Square-Cube Law), more streamlined rocket will have a higher terminal velocity, and thus ascend more efficiently with higher TWR and a steeper/earlier gravity-turn; whereas smaller, less streamlined rockets will ascend more efficiently with lower TWR and a more gentle/late gravity turn...

And, of course, as I've pointed out many times before, the goal of a space program is almost never merely to make it to Low Earth Orbit in real life. IF you're trying to get to a higher orbit than 72 x 72 km, your ideal ascent profile changes substantially: generally you want to make your gravity-turn a bit later and slower when launching directly to a higher orbit (and you generally want to launch to a higher orbit than 72 x 72 km so that your orbit won't turn you too much when making a long ejection-burn: although periapsis-kicks are an option to help get around that...)

Launching directly to slightly higher orbits (say 150 km instead of 75 km) is generally more fuel-efficient when you're trying to get beyond LKO as it gives you more time to perform your circularization burn, and thus allows you to get by with a lower upper-stage TWR (which allows you to increase your total Delta-V with better fuel-fraction or higher-ISP engines...) and also allows you to perform your ejection-burns over a longer period of time or more accurately...

Also, the ascent profile that will get you to orbit with the most mass remaining (including engine and empty fuel tank mass), most Delta-V remaining (a combination of fuel-fraction and engine ISP), and most fuel remaining are generally different things. Rockets with higher upper-stage TWR ratings (in multi-stage rockets) will often get to orbit with more total mass, but less fuel: which can be useful if you plan on refueling and using that upper stage as a transfer-stage for a substantially-larger interplanetary vessel, for instance, but sub-optimal for a one-off mission profile. There's also the trade-off between TWR and ISP in your engines: a rocket with higher-thrust (but lower ISP) upper stage engines might consume less fuel to get you to orbit (due to shorter time-to-orbit), but actually leave you with less Delta-V to get where you're heading in the long run...

Trying to optimize rocket designs is what real-life rocket scientists spend DECADES on. In short, don't think you're going to fully understand it after some back-of-the envelope calculations: I've been playing KSP for over a year and a half and I'm STILL learning new things about optimal rocket designs (and for extra fun, I play with FAR, RealFuels, and Real Solar System 64K- which all change the optimal rocket designs substantially...)

Regards,

Northstar

Edited February 2, 2015 by Northstar1989
